ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned SO much about Victorian Spiritualism. You will leave this course extremely knowledgeable on the subject.
This class made me think a lot about how science and spiritualism interacted in the Victorian era. I also learned how to think about and use unreliable or questionable primary sources.

This is an amazing course. You get to learn about British history and the Victorian era through a really interesting lens. The subject matter is fascinating and I was always so engaged and invested in class discussions and readings. The writing assignments were also so much fun as our course materials were so interesting.
Historical writing, deep and close reading
European history during the 19th century and its relation to spiritualism and the occult was the focal point of the class, but I was also able to learn its impact on society and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths of this course are Dr. Temple and the amazing primary sources she's picked out. The secondary sources for homework were far less engaging but at least you come away with a lot of knowledge.
This is a great course! I especially liked the trips to the YUAG and Beinecke, and I got a lot out of the regular seminar sessions.

the main weakness of this course is a lack of ground-laying in terms of corrects terms for sensitive topics. For example, a certain reading used outdated and offensive terms for the LGBTQ+ community, especially in regards to sexual activity, and the issues were never acknowledged, but were encouraged by both the professor and students. This class would benefit from updated secondary sources that reflect the language of today, and the instructor would do good to establish what is and is not accurate or acceptable in the classroom setting.

Strengths: amazing class discussions, readings, and materials were so interesting

Weaknesses: sometimes readings assignments were a bit too long (we had to read an entire book for one class), so I think the syllabus could be shortened so that we had more time to discuss important readings. Also, I would have appreciated more directions on the short essays! The directions given were a bit confusing

Strength: the course subject! So interesting and so were many of the readings. I also enjoyed the slow build up to the final research paper; it was well paced and didnt feel overwhelming 

Weaknesses: none I can think of

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the 19th century or the occult. Be ready to read some of the most shocking first-hand accounts of walking tables and evil spirits you're likely to find in any college course at Yale.

I would definitely recommend this course! It was really fun, and you get to look at a good mix of primary and secondary resources. As a non-history major, I thought the class was accessible, and I know the questions and ideas raised in this class will stick with me for a very long time.

Yes!!!!! This was one of the most fun, engaging courses I have ever taken. I learned so much and my writing improved tremendously. Dr T is an incredible professor - she is so great at facilitating meaningful discussion and gives great feedback on papers.
Absolutely, it was overall a very interesting class.
